an7.47:4.1: Now at that time the brahmin Uggatasarīra had prepared a great sacrifice.
an7.47:4.2: Bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats and rams—five hundred of each—had been led to the post for the sacrifice.
an7.47:4.3: Then the brahmin Uggatasarīra went up to the Buddha,
an7.47:4.5: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
an7.47:5.1: “Master Gotama, I have heard that kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post is very fruitful and beneficial.”
an7.47:5.4: and third time Uggatasarīra said to the Buddha:
an7.47:5.5: “Master Gotama, I have heard that kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post is very fruitful and beneficial.”
an7.47:5.7: “Then Master Gotama and I are in total agreement in this matter.”
an7.47:6.1: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to Uggatasarīra:
an7.47:6.2: “Brahmin, you shouldn’t ask the Buddha in this way.
an7.47:6.4: You should ask in this way:
an7.47:6.5: ‘Sir, I want to kindle the sacrificial fire and raise the sacrificial post.
an7.47:6.7: and instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’”
an7.47:7.1: Then Uggatasarīra said to the Buddha:
an7.47:7.2: “Sir, I want to kindle the sacrificial fire and raise the sacrificial post.
an7.47:7.4: and instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’”
an7.47:8.1: “Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one raises three unwholesome knives which ripen and result in suffering.
an7.47:8.3: The knives of the body, speech, and mind.
an7.47:8.4: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one gives rise to the thought:
an7.47:8.5: ‘May this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams be slaughtered for the sacrifice!’
an7.47:8.6: Thinking, ‘May I make merit’, one makes bad karma. Thinking, ‘May I do good’, one does bad. Thinking, ‘May I seek the path to a good rebirth’, one seeks the path to a bad rebirth.
an7.47:8.7: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one raises this first unwholesome mental knife which ripens and results in suffering.
an7.47:9.1: Furthermore, even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one says such things as:
an7.47:9.2: ‘May this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams be slaughtered for the sacrifice!’
an7.47:9.3: Thinking, ‘May I make merit’, one makes bad karma. Thinking, ‘May I do good’, one does bad. Thinking, ‘May I seek the path to a good rebirth’, one seeks the path to a bad rebirth.
an7.47:9.4: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one raises this second unwholesome verbal knife which ripens and results in suffering.
an7.47:10.1: Furthermore, even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one first personally undertakes preparations for the sacrificial slaughter of bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams.
an7.47:10.2: Thinking, ‘May I make merit’, one makes bad karma. Thinking, ‘May I do good’, one does bad. Thinking, ‘May I seek the path to a good rebirth’, one seeks the path to a bad rebirth.
an7.47:10.3: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one raises this third unwholesome bodily knife which ripens and results in suffering.
an7.47:10.4: Even before kindling the sacrificial fire and raising the sacrificial post one raises these three unwholesome knives which ripen and result in suffering.
an7.47:11.1: Brahmin, these three fires should be given up and rejected, not cultivated.
an7.47:11.3: The fires of greed, hate, and delusion.
an7.47:12.1: And why should the fire of greed be given up and rejected, not cultivated?
an7.47:12.2: A greedy person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an7.47:12.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an7.47:12.4: That’s why the fire of greed should be given up and rejected, not cultivated.
an7.47:13.1: And why should the fire of hate be given up and rejected, not cultivated?
an7.47:13.2: A hateful person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an7.47:13.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an7.47:13.4: That’s why the fire of hate should be given up and rejected, not cultivated.
an7.47:14.1: And why should the fire of delusion be given up and rejected, not cultivated?
an7.47:14.2: A deluded person does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
an7.47:14.3: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an7.47:14.4: That’s why the fire of delusion should be given up and rejected, not cultivated.
an7.47:14.5: These three fires should be given up and rejected, not cultivated.
an7.47:15.1: Brahmin, you should properly and happily take care of three fires, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating them.
an7.47:15.3: The fire of those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods. The fire of a householder. And the fire of those worthy of a teacher’s offering.
an7.47:16.1: And what is the fire of those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods?
an7.47:16.2: Your mother and father are called the fire of those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.
an7.47:16.4: Since it is from them that you’ve been incubated and produced. So you should properly and happily take care of this fire, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating it.
an7.47:17.1: And what is the fire of a householder?
an7.47:17.2: Your children, partners, slaves, servants, and workers are called a householder’s fire.
an7.47:17.3: So you should properly and happily take care of this fire, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating it.
an7.47:18.1: And what is the fire of those worthy of a teacher’s offering?
an7.47:18.2: The ascetics and brahmins who avoid intoxication and negligence, are settled in acceptance and sweetness, and who tame, calm, and extinguish themselves are called the fire of those worthy of a teacher’s offering.
an7.47:18.3: So you should properly and happily take care of this fire, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating it.
an7.47:18.4: You should properly and happily take care of these three fires, honoring, respecting, esteeming, and venerating them.
an7.47:19.1: But the wood fire, brahmin, should, from time to time, be fanned, watched over with equanimity, extinguished, or put aside.”
an7.47:20.1: When he said this, the brahmin Uggatasarīra said to the Buddha:
an7.47:20.3: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
an7.47:20.4: Master Gotama, I now set free these five hundred bulls, five hundred bullocks, five hundred heifers, five hundred goats, and five hundred rams. I give them life!
an7.47:20.5: May they eat grass and drink cool water and enjoy a cool breeze!”
